data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Connecting to Nature: Mindfulness and Desire to Engage in Pro-Environmental Behaviors

sample.value: The determined sample size is 128 participants, 32 participants in each condition. Due to the exclusion criteria, we may need to recruit more participants.

analyses.value: I will be using two separate ANOVAs to see how participants in each condition differ from the other conditions on connectedness to nature, and desire for pro-environmental behaviors. I will also be using a mediation analysis to see if the relationship between mindfulness practice and pro-environmental behaviors is partially mediated by connectedness to nature. Lastly, I will conduct a moderated mediation to see if the use of a phone after the mindfulness practice interferes the relationship with connectedness to nature and pro-environmental behaviors.

outliers.value: For this study the exclusion criteria consists of participants being unable to answer the attention question, the name of the recording that was played. Also, if the participant practices mindfulness or yoga more than once a week.

dependent.value: Connectedness to nature will be measured through a self-report questionnaire using the State Connectedness to Nature Scale. Desire to engage in pro-environmental behaviors will be measured through a self-report questionnaire using a revised Pro-Environmental Behavior Scale.

conditions.value: There will be four conditions that participants can be assigned to, they will only be assigned to one condition out of the four. A mindfulness practice and no phone, mindfulness practice and phone, progressive muscle relaxation and no phone, and progressive muscle relaxation and phone.

hypothesis.value: Does practicing mindfulness increase individuals' desire to engage in pro-environmental behaviors, and would using a phone after the practice interfere with the effects of the mindfulness.

attributes.title: Social and Technical Approaches to Problem Solving

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Social and Technical Approaches to Problem Solving

sample.value: Sample Size - We aim to recruit 400 participants in total, with 200 male participants and 200 female participants for the first phase of the study. Due to possible attrition and non-completion of tasks, we expect that our usable sample will reflect 80-90% of our initial recruitment.

analyses.value:
Analyses 
1. Bivariate correlations (Pearson’s r) will be calculated to assess relationships among the variables. Bivariate correlations will serve as preliminary tests of our predictions. 

2. Hierarchical regressions will be used to assess whether sociality predicts independent variance in technical problem solving and social problem solving, independent of technical orientation. These regressions will also test whether social and technical orientation interact in predicting social and technical problem solving. 

3. T-tests will assess whether social problem solving is more common than technical problem solving in the three scenarios. 

4. Dummy variable multiple regression will assess whether women are more likely to solve problems socially and men are more likely to solve problems technically. 

5. Regression analyses will be conducted to test the mediational model, according to which women report higher social orientation and lower technical orientation, and these in turn mediate the effect of gender on social and technical problem solving. 

6. Logistic regression will be used to determine if higher sociality and lower technicality mediate the decreased tendency for women to modify/innovate new products. 

In relation to the dependent variable Tendency to Innovate, when using an MTurk sample it can be difficult to verify if participants have legitimately modified or invented. Consequently, we will use logistic regression to analyse the data relating to this question in three ways, from least conservative to most conservative: 

1. Take the information they have provided at face value – we will treat all instances in which they claim to have engaged in modification/invention as correct.

2. We will treat all instances in which they claim to have engaged in modification/invention as correct except those cases in which we can rule out participants by what they have written to describe their modification/invention. For example, if someone says they modified their flash light and describes it as changing batteries, this does not count as a modification or an invention. Consequently, this person would be ruled out. Unclear responses such as “I have modified my torch”, which lacks detail but claim modification/invention will be considered valid in this second analysis.

3. We will only consider a case as a valid modification/invention if participants have written something that indicates that a modification/invention has occurred.

outliers.value: Outliers and Exclusions - Univariate outliers will be determined using Field’s (2009, p.153) criteria (z > +/- 3.29). Multivariate outliers will be determined using Cook’s Distance (Cook, 1977) criteria (Di > 1). All analyses will be run with and without outliers, however results are expected to be similar despite their presence or absence (with possibility for weaker results when analysing with outliers present).

dependent.value:
Problem Solving:

Participants are asked to solve three separate problem scenarios devised by our lab. These problems have been constructed so that solutions/responses could be either technically or socially based. Responses provided by participants to these three problem-solving scenarios will be coded by research assistants in Part Two according to the following rubric. 

• Technical problem-solving – Technical problem-solving is defined as the modification of an existing physical product that alters and/or improves the functionality of the original product, or creation of a brand-new physical product de novo. Technical problem solving may or may not be innovative, depending on whether these modifications or creations are new to the user or the world. 

• Social problem-solving – Social problem-solving relies on the combined efforts of more than one individual, without the creation or modification of products. Social problem-solving can involve the creation or modification of techniques. Social problem solving may or may not be innovative, depending on whether the social solutions are new to the user or the world.

conditions.value:
The RIASEC Test – We are using items from the RIASEC (realistic, investigative, artistic, social, enterprising, conventional) test to assess participants’ interests (Holland, 1959; 1997). Our focus will be the realistic, investigative, and social items. 

Tendency to Innovate – We are using items from von Hippel, de Jong and Flowers (2012) to assess participants’ propensity to modify or create new products, i.e., to solve problems technically. 

Gender – (self-rated) We will measure gender of participants using four items; (1) Male, (2) Female, (3) Other (*with text box to state gender identification). Analyses will be restricted to participants who select male or female. 

Ethnicity – (self-rated) Ethnicity is chosen from the following list; (1) White, (2) Hispanic/Latino , (3) Black/African American, (4) Native American/American Indian, (5) Asian, (6) Pacific Islander, (7) Other (*with text box to state ethnicity). These data will not be used in analyses, but rather to describe our sample. 

Level of Education completed Level of education will be chosen from the following list; (1) Some High School, (2) High School graduate, Diploma received, (3) Some College/University, (4) Trade/technical/vocational training (5) College/University Graduate, (6) Master’s Degree (MS), (8) Doctoral Degree (PhD), (7) Professional Degree (MD, JD, etc). These data will not be used in the analyses, but rather to describe our sample. Nonetheless, all analyses will be conducted with and without education as a control variable, and the results should be the same in both cases.

Age - Age will be measured using the following list; (1) under 20 years old, (2) 20 to 25, (3) 26 to 30, (4) 31 to 35, (5) 36 to 40, (6) 41 to 45, (7) 46 to 50, (8) 51 to 55, (9) 56 to 60, (10) 61 to 65, (11) 66+. These data will not be used in analyses, but rather to describe our sample. Again, all analyses will be conducted with and without age as a control variable, and the results should be the same in both cases.

hypothesis.value:
1. Both men and women will solve problems more frequently using social rather than technical means. 

2. Males will solve problems technically more than females, and females will solve problems socially more than males. 

3. This gender difference will be mediated by differences in sociality and technical orientation, such that:
a) Males will show lower levels of sociality than females, and individuals who show lower sociality will solve problems technically more and socially less than individuals who show higher levels of sociality. 
b) Males will show higher levels of technical orientation than females, and individuals who show higher technical orientation will solve problems technically more than individuals who show lower levels of technical orientation. 

4. Sociality will predict unique variance in decreased technical and increased social problem solving beyond that predicted by technical orientation. 

5. Technical and social orientations will interact, such that people are particularly likely to solve problems technically when they have low social and high technical orientation. In other words, the effect of technical orientation on technical problem solving will be strongest among people low in sociality.

attributes.title: Integrated palliative care education for trainees in primary and specialty tracks: a scoping review.
attributes.description: This study is a scoping review of the PC education currently available to graduate medical trainees in primary and specialty tracks.

summary.value: Prior discussions regarding PC education in training programs clearly demonstrate an interest and need for integration and effective training. A review since the establishment of HPM fellowships has not been performed nor has there been an assessment of the current integrated PC educational curricula in non-HPM training programs. This study is a scoping review with an expanded search of PC educational interventions including residents and fellows in all medical specialties. It is unique in that it reviews education interventions, already existing or newly developed, by medical subspecialty.

registration_responses.summary: Prior discussions regarding PC education in training programs clearly demonstrate an interest and need for integration and effective training. attributes.title: Understanding the effects of text reminders on reducing churn in supplemental assistance programs
attributes.description: “Churning” is when eligible transitional benefit program participants fail to renew, temporarily dropping out of their program before reentering within four months. Churn is a widespread issue across transitional benefit programs, negatively impacting participants and administering agencies. This proposed intervention will assess whether a low-cost scalable texting program can reduce churn for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Participants in one treatment group will receive text messages that simplify the interim report and recertification process with reminders, information, and direct links. A second treatment arm will receive reminders only, while a control group will experience the current procedures of the Massachusetts Department of Transitional Assistance. The text messages aim to reduce informational and behavioral barriers program participants face and thus lessen churn. We estimate an overall sample size around 60,000 over the course of three months. We will iterate three times during the project, testing timing of the texts and identifying heterogeneous effects. The primary outcome of interest is churn probability. We will also assess completing process steps on time rates, submitting complete forms or verification rates, interview completion rates (including as-scheduled and post-missed interview), approval and closure rates, and the average number of days that forms are submitted before deadlines.

q1.value: Understanding the Effects of Text Reminders on Reducing Churn in Supplemental Assistance Programs

q2.value: Samuel M Madison, Susanna Loeb, Katharine Meyer

q4.value:
The proposed research project aims to address the following hypotheses about how transitional benefit recipients navigate processes for determining eligibility and continued benefits receipt: 

(1) We hypothesize that a text-messaging program can reduce churn for SNAP recipients.

(2) We hypothesize that there may be specific characteristics of text-messages that drive the effects (e.g., simply reminders about upcoming due dates or reminders coupled with links to additional resources).

Our research contributes to a growing body of research on text-based communications to understand the contexts in which outreach is most effect and the characteristics of communications that are more successful in encouraging individuals to complete an important task or procedure.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
For this intervention, we will randomly assign SNAP benefit participants who are due for their interim report or re-certification and are thus at risk of churning into groups. The first treatment group will receive text message reminders about key steps, a phone number that they can call to receive help, and hyperlinks to the website and mobile application where clients can submit their forms. This treatment addresses informational constraints such as lack of information on how and where to file the paperwork. It also addresses the behavioral barriers created by cognitive load by including easy links and holds client attention through reminders. A second treatment arm will receive reminders only. All text messages will include a note that recipients can “Text STOP to end messages.” The control group consists of participants receiving the standard letters and automated phone calls currently in effect. 

This research design answers these key questions:
(1) can a text-messaging program reduce churn; and 
(2) do reminders drive the effects or is a reduction in cognitive load through easy to implement steps necessary to reduce churn. 

The comparison of the two treatments provides evidence on whether reminders alone are beneficial or whether easing the processes and reducing the cognitive load are necessary. We will run the intervention for three months and then iterate on the texts, aiming to identify particularly promising practices. The large sample and the ability to iterate will allow us to explore whether the time of day or day of the week for texts effect their impact, as was found for parent texting;  what the optimal number of text messages is;  and whether certain groups respond differentially including groups by age, location, children, work history, and race/ethnicity. Texting programs are unusually easy to implement with fidelity and we are using available data. 

All SNAP recipients who are due for their interim report or re-certification and who have provided their phone number to DTA will be considered for this intervention. We have only limited information on the opt-out rates, but believe that 20 percent is a conservative estimate, given opt-out from other studies. While DTA’s caseload fluctuates, a conservative estimate of approximately 10,000 re-certification forms and 15,000 Interim Reports (IRs) will be due every month for SIMP-12 SNAP clients. With an opt out rate of 20 percent, we will have a monthly sample size of around 8,000 household heads (10,000 re-certification due x 80%=8,000) who will need to complete re-certification forms, and of 12,000 household heads (15,000 IRs due x 80%=12,000) who will need to complete an IR.
	
Given the nature of this project, we intend to treat the maximum number of eligible participants. We intend to first field this intervention for three months (February 2020 through May 2020) and estimate an overall sample size around 51,000 clients who DTA has permission to communicate with via text message. Using Optimal Design based on a single level person randomized trial for the calculations, we expect to be able to find acceptable minimal detectable effects sizes (MDE) with this sample. The MDE of a binary treatment comparison (C vs T1, C vs T2, or T1 vs T2) for a power of 80 percent, a significance level of 5 percent, and sample sizes of between 60 percent and a 20 percent opt out rate. We anticipate these opt-out rates are much higher than we will encounter with the intervention, since clients have already had the opportunity to opt-out of text message communication. In the worst expected case, with an opt-out rate of 60 percent (51,000*0.4=20,400), comparing two treatment groups (20,400*2/3=13,600) and an R2 of three percent, we will be able to detect effects of a size of 0.047 standard deviations (SD) or larger for any binary treatment comparison. In more likely scenarios, we will be able to detect effect sizes as low as 0.028 SDs. Given a historic average churn of 22 percent (SD=0.414), these effect sizes translate to detecting MDEs between 1.2-1.9 percentage points. Previous related studies find larger or similar effect sizes. 
	
We will estimate the average treatment effect in a straightforward linear model:
Y_i=β_0+β_1 T_i^1+β_2 T_i^2+X_i β_3+ε_i where Y_i is the outcome of interest of household head i (submission of re-certification form or interim report, SNAP benefit renewal), and T_i^1 and T_i^2 are binary indicators for treatment groups. We will include participant background characteristics, X_i, to improve precision but they should not affect point estimates.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: The research team will not access DTA participant data until prior to treatment. This registration will occur prior to the research team accessing the data.

question.value:
The data will be securely received from the Massachusetts Department of Transitional Assistance (MA-DTA) utilizing the Brown University Stronghold system. The data does not contain any personally identifiable data about recipients or household members (such as name, birthdate, or address) and solely contains a unique ID which will enable us to establish key linkages in the dataset.

All SNAP recipients who come up for an interim report or re-certification during our study period will automatically be in the study. MA-DTA owns the data and is able to release the data to us under the agreements we have set forth under our Data Sharing Agreement (signed 10/9/2019).

DTA will provide the Brown research team with data regarding SNAP-only individuals/households with a reporting type of Simplified Reporting and a certification length of 12 months ("Simp-12" clients). Households with a domestic violence indicator will be excluded.

The participant population: 

All SNAP recipients who are due for their interim report or recertification and who have provided their phone number to DTA will be considered for this intervention. While DTA’s caseload fluctuates, a conservative estimate of approximately 10,000 recertification forms and 15,000 IRs will be due every month for SIMP-12 SNAP clients. With an estimated text-message opt out rate of 20 percent, we will have a monthly sample size of around 8,000 household heads (10,000 recertification due x 80%=8,000) who will need to complete recertification forms, and of 12,000 household heads (15,000 IRs due x 80%=12,000) who will need to complete an IR.

There are no exclusion restrictions

Our recruitment is limited to the number of clients using SNAP benefits and who come up for an interim report or re-certification during the course of the project. We anticipate running the intervention for three three-month cycles, and estimate between 90,000-180,000 benefit recipients will participation in the intervention, depending on the opt-out rate from receiving text messages. We will track opt-out rates to measure differential attrition by treatment group.

registration_responses.q1: Understanding the Effects of Text Reminders on Reducing Churn in Supplemental Assistance Programs
registration_responses.q2: Samuel M Madison, Susanna Loeb, Katharine Meyer
registration_responses.q3: “Churning” is when eligible transitional benefit program participants fail to renew, temporarily dropping out of their program before reentering within four months. Churn is a widespread issue across transitional benefit programs, negatively impacting participants and administering agencies. This proposed intervention will assess whether a low-cost scalable texting program can reduce churn for the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Participants in one treatment group will receive text messages that simplify the interim report and re-certification process with reminders, information, and direct links. A second treatment arm will receive reminders only, while a control group will experience the current procedures of the Massachusetts Department of Transitional Assistance. The text messages aim to reduce informational and behavioral barriers program participants face and thus lessen churn. We estimate an overall sample size around 60,000 over the course of three months. We will iterate three times during the project, testing timing of the texts and identifying heterogeneous effects. The primary outcome of interest is churn probability. We will also assess completing process steps on time rates, submitting complete forms or verification rates, interview completion rates (including as-scheduled and post-missed interview), approval and closure rates, and the average number of days that forms are submitted before deadlines.
registration_responses.q4:
The proposed research project aims to address the following hypotheses about how transitional benefit recipients navigate processes for determining eligibility and continued benefits receipt: 

(1) We hypothesize that a text-messaging program can reduce churn for SNAP recipients.

(2) We hypothesize that there may be specific characteristics of text-messages that drive the effects (e.g., simply reminders about upcoming due dates or reminders coupled with links to additional resources).

Our research contributes to a growing body of research on text-based communications to understand the contexts in which outreach is most effect and the characteristics of communications that are more successful in encouraging individuals to complete an important task or procedure.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9:
We will randomly assign SNAP benefit participants who are due for their interim report or re-certification and are thus at risk of churning into three groups:  

(T1) The first treatment group will receive text message reminders about key steps, a phone number that they can call to receive help, and hyperlinks to the website and mobile application where clients can submit their forms.

(T2) A second treatment arm will receive text reminders only.

(C) A control group consisting of participants receiving the standard letters and automated phone calls currently in effect.

All SNAP recipients who are due for their interim report or re-certification and who have provided their phone number to DTA will be considered for this intervention.

We intend to first field this intervention for three months (February 2020 through May 2020) and estimate an overall sample size around 60,000. Using Optimal Design based on a single level person randomized trial for the calculations, we expect to be able to find acceptable minimal detectable effects sizes (MDE). In the worst expected case, with an opt-out rate of 60 percent (75,000*0.4=30,000), comparing two treatment groups (30,000*2/3=20,000) and an R2 of three percent, we will be able to detect effects of a size of 0.039 standard deviations (SD) or larger for any binary treatment comparison. In more likely scenarios, we will be able to detect effect sizes as low as 0.026 SDs. Given a historic average churn of 22 percent (SD=0.414), these effect sizes translate to detecting MDEs between 1.1-1.6 percentage points.

Y_i=β_0+β_1 T_i^1+β_2 T_i^2+X_i β_3+ε_i
where Y_i is the outcome of interest of household head i (submission of recertification form or interim report, SNAP benefit renewal), and T_i^1 and T_i^2 are binary indicators for treatment groups. We will include participant background characteristics, X_i, to improve precision but they should not affect point estimates.

registration_responses.q8.question:
For this intervention, we will randomly assign SNAP benefit participants who are due for their interim report or re-certification and are thus at risk of churning into groups. The first treatment group will receive text message reminders about key steps, a phone number that they can call to receive help, and hyperlinks to the website and mobile application where clients can submit their forms. This treatment addresses informational constraints such as lack of information on how and where to file the paperwork. It also addresses the behavioral barriers created by cognitive load by including easy links and holds client attention through reminders. A second treatment arm will receive reminders only. All text messages will include a note that recipients can “Text STOP to end messages.” The control group consists of participants receiving the standard letters and automated phone calls currently in effect. 

This research design answers these key questions:
(1) can a text-messaging program reduce churn; and 
(2) do reminders drive the effects or is a reduction in cognitive load through easy to implement steps necessary to reduce churn. 

The comparison of the two treatments provides evidence on whether reminders alone are beneficial or whether easing the processes and reducing the cognitive load are necessary. We will run the intervention for three months and then iterate on the texts, aiming to identify particularly promising practices. The large sample and the ability to iterate will allow us to explore whether the time of day or day of the week for texts effect their impact, as was found for parent texting;  what the optimal number of text messages is;  and whether certain groups respond differentially including groups by age, location, children, work history, and race/ethnicity. Texting programs are unusually easy to implement with fidelity and we are using available data. 

All SNAP recipients who are due for their interim report or re-certification and who have provided their phone number to DTA will be considered for this intervention. We have only limited information on the opt-out rates, but believe that 20 percent is a conservative estimate, given opt-out from other studies. While DTA’s caseload fluctuates, a conservative estimate of approximately 10,000 re-certification forms and 15,000 Interim Reports (IRs) will be due every month for SIMP-12 SNAP clients. With an opt out rate of 20 percent, we will have a monthly sample size of around 8,000 household heads (10,000 re-certification due x 80%=8,000) who will need to complete re-certification forms, and of 12,000 household heads (15,000 IRs due x 80%=12,000) who will need to complete an IR.
	
Given the nature of this project, we intend to treat the maximum number of eligible participants. We intend to first field this intervention for three months (February 2020 through May 2020) and estimate an overall sample size around 51,000 clients who DTA has permission to communicate with via text message. Using Optimal Design based on a single level person randomized trial for the calculations, we expect to be able to find acceptable minimal detectable effects sizes (MDE) with this sample. The MDE of a binary treatment comparison (C vs T1, C vs T2, or T1 vs T2) for a power of 80 percent, a significance level of 5 percent, and sample sizes of between 60 percent and a 20 percent opt out rate. We anticipate these opt-out rates are much higher than we will encounter with the intervention, since clients have already had the opportunity to opt-out of text message communication. In the worst expected case, with an opt-out rate of 60 percent (51,000*0.4=20,400), comparing two treatment groups (20,400*2/3=13,600) and an R2 of three percent, we will be able to detect effects of a size of 0.047 standard deviations (SD) or larger for any binary treatment comparison. In more likely scenarios, we will be able to detect effect sizes as low as 0.028 SDs. Given a historic average churn of 22 percent (SD=0.414), these effect sizes translate to detecting MDEs between 1.2-1.9 percentage points. Previous related studies find larger or similar effect sizes. 
	
We will estimate the average treatment effect in a straightforward linear model:
Y_i=β_0+β_1 T_i^1+β_2 T_i^2+X_i β_3+ε_i where Y_i is the outcome of interest of household head i (submission of re-certification form or interim report, SNAP benefit renewal), and T_i^1 and T_i^2 are binary indicators for treatment groups. We will include participant background characteristics, X_i, to improve precision but they should not affect point estimates.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The data will be securely received from the Massachusetts Department of Transitional Assistance (MA-DTA) utilizing the Brown University Stronghold system. The data does not contain any personally identifiable data about recipients or household members (such as name, birthdate, or address) and solely contains a unique ID which will enable us to establish key linkages in the dataset.

All SNAP recipients who come up for an interim report or re-certification during our study period will automatically be in the study. MA-DTA owns the data and is able to release the data to us under the agreements we have set forth under our Data Sharing Agreement (signed 10/9/2019).

DTA will provide the Brown research team with data regarding SNAP-only individuals/households with a reporting type of Simplified Reporting and a certification length of 12 months ("Simp-12" clients). Households with a domestic violence indicator will be excluded.

The participant population: 

All SNAP recipients who are due for their interim report or recertification and who have provided their phone number to DTA will be considered for this intervention. While DTA’s caseload fluctuates, a conservative estimate of approximately 10,000 recertification forms and 15,000 IRs will be due every month for SIMP-12 SNAP clients. With an estimated text-message opt out rate of 20 percent, we will have a monthly sample size of around 8,000 household heads (10,000 recertification due x 80%=8,000) who will need to complete recertification forms, and of 12,000 household heads (15,000 IRs due x 80%=12,000) who will need to complete an IR.

There are no exclusion restrictions

Our recruitment is limited to the number of clients using SNAP benefits and who come up for an interim report or re-certification during the course of the project. We anticipate running the intervention for three three-month cycles, and estimate between 90,000-180,000 benefit recipients will participation in the intervention, depending on the opt-out rate from receiving text messages. We will track opt-out rates to measure differential attrition by treatment group.

attributes.title: Inferring mental states from static scenes

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Inferring mental states from static scenes - Kids forced-choice

other.value:
We are also collecting information about how children search through the warm-up drawers, and the counting strategies they use when counting the number of drawers. These will be used for exploratory analyses. We will also do an exploratory analysis of how the proportion of correct answers changes with participant age. 

A small number of data has already been collected for the full sample, but has not yet been analyzed. Statistical analyses will begin once the full sample of N=35 is collected.

sample.value: A pilot sample of 10 participants was collected, and used to determine the necessary sample size for a one-tailed binomial test. Based on the results of this pilot (proportion correct = 0.72), a significance level of 0.05, and power of 0.85, we will collect a sample size of 35 children for the full study.

analyses.value: A binomial test will be carried out for each of the 6 questions in order to assess if the proportion of correct answers for each question is above chance (0.5).

outliers.value:
Exclusion criteria: 
a. Experimenter Error: If the experimenter incorrectly administers the task (e.g., asks the test questions incorrectly, inadvertently directs the participant towards a particular answer).
b. Family interference: If parent or sibling interferes in the task (e.g., telling the participant what to choose or distracting the child from the task by talking to them or touching the stimuli while the participant is playing the games responding to any of the verbal questions before the participant has a chance to respond).
c. Language issues: If the participant does not understand the task instructions because of language difficulties (e.g., not fluent in English).
d. Voluntarily withdrawing: If the participant or their parent/legal guardian chooses to withdraw before the task is complete or does not answer the test questions.
e. Attention Issues: If the child is not visibly attending to the Experimenter (e.g., hiding during the task, failing to interact with the stimuli by talking over the experimenter, giving an answer before the experimenter has asked the test question).

dependent.value:
Each participant will be given 6 trials. During each trial, the participant will be read a sentence describing a character’s mental state, and then presented with a forced-choice option between two different images that contain different numbers and orientations of open drawers. 

The dependent variable is the child’s choice of which image best matches the story during each trial.

conditions.value: There is only one condition. The presentation of the 6 different trials will be randomized for each participant.

hypothesis.value:
The main question being tested in this study is if children are able to infer mental states from static images of a person’s actions. Specifically, children will be told what a person knew about where something was hidden in a set of drawers (e.g. they knew exactly where it was, they had no idea, they didn’t know but then they remembered), and then asked to choose between two possible images showing different patterns of open drawers, indicating where someone had searched. 

The task begins with a warm-up game where children are shown a set of small 3d plastic drawers, and asked to count the drawers, and then search for a sticker hidden in one of the drawers. 

Following this warmup, children are shown cards containing a sentence describing the mental state of the character, and the two images to choose between. 

Mental states tested include: 
1. She knew exactly where the sticker was hidden (target image shows only one drawer open).
2. She had no idea where the sticker was hidden (target image shows efficient search).
3. She had no idea where the sticker was hidden (target image shows random search).
4. At first, she didn’t know where the sticker was hidden, but then she remembered (target image shows a series of drawers open along the top row, and then one addition drawer at the bottom right).
5. She knew about the area where the sticker was hidden (target image shows a square of 4 drawers open at the center of the dresser).
6. She was not looking for anything, she was just opening drawers for fun (target image shows every other drawer open, creating a checkerboard pattern). 

If children are able to match the correct image with the mental state that led to the particular pattern of open drawers, it suggests that they are able to use patterns of data in the environment to infer mental states of others around them. This would extend our understanding of theory of mind, where a child understands that others have different beliefs than they do, and demonstrate that they can use this ability to allow them to understand the actions that would result from a person having a certain belief or mental state.

attributes.title: National Survey of Police Officer-Involved Firearms Shootings
attributes.description:
NORC at the University of Chicago and the Police Executive Research Forum (PERF) will conduct a national organizational survey of law enforcement agencies (LEAs) to estimate the agency aggregated numbers of the past 10 years of police officer-involved shootings—including both officers shooting at civilians and officers being shot or shot at—and demographic, situational, agency, and community factors associated with these shootings. This is one of the first national studies to assess the number of officers shooting civilians and officers being shot at in the same dataset, and to measure important correlates of these shootings using advanced analytical methods. This study addresses two important gaps: First, we do not have reliable nationally representative data to estimate the number of police officers shootings of civilians, the number of police officers being shot at, and the overlap between the two. Second, there is little research on how LEA characteristics, structure, resources, culture, policies and training are related to officer-involved shootings.

Using a stratified sample design developed by NORC and implemented by PERF, we will randomly draw a nationally representative sample of 1,500 LEAs. We will invite the selected LEAs to participate in an online survey. With an estimated 70% response rate, we expect at least 1,000 LEAs will complete the survey. The sample will be weighted to be representative of all state/local LEAs in the U.S., adjusting for non-response. We will also explore the potential use of existing datasets, including UCR, local gun law and regulation, and census data, for measures of agency and community correlates, and merge it with our national survey data when possible. In addition, we will select 30 agencies to conduct in-depth interviews with command staff to provide additional context for our survey data.

q1.value: A National Survey of Police Officer-Involved Firearms Shootings

q2.value: Jackie Sheridan, Bruce Taylor, Weiwei Liu

q3.value:
Notwithstanding deeply-rooted concerns regarding officer use of deadly force and officers’ safety in communities, there is a lack of data-driven guidance on mechanisms to reduce officer involved shootings and protect police officers and the public. Media, federal and survey data undercount officer-involved shootings and contain a limited number of community, agency and situational correlates. Despite research demonstrating the correlation between adverse community characteristics such as poverty and officer involved shootings, we have limited national data on this issue. 

NORC at the University of Chicago and the Police Executive Research Forum (PERF) will conduct a national organizational survey of law enforcement agencies (LEAs) to estimate the agency aggregated numbers of the past 10 years of police officer-involved shootings—including both officers shooting at civilians and officers being shot or shot at—and demographic, situational, agency, and community factors associated with these shootings. This is the first national study to assess the number of officers shooting civilians and officers being shot at in the same dataset, and to measure important correlates of these shootings using advanced analytical methods. This study addresses two important gaps: First, we do not have reliable nationally representative data to estimate the number of police officers shootings of civilians, the number of police officers being shot at, and the overlap between the two. Second, there is little research on how LEA characteristics, structure, resources, culture, policies and training are related to officer-involved shootings. 

We propose three research questions. RQ1: How many civilians did police officers shoot with a firearm and how many police officers were shot at in the past ten years, total and by citizen and officer demographics and situational factors? RQ2: To what extent are agency characteristics, culture, practices and training related to the number/rate of officer-involved shootings? RQ3: Are community factors, such as local gun laws and restrictions and gun violence rates related to agency culture, policing practices and required training and to the number/rate of officer-involved shootings? RQ2 and RQ3 will be examined in terms of both overall officer-involved shootings and broken down by officer and citizen demographics and situational factors, separately for (a) officers shooting civilians and (b) officers being shot at.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that:
1) The number/rate of officers shooting citizens and officers being shot at will be positively correlated.
2) The number/rate of officer-involved shootings will vary by citizen and officer demographics and situational factors.
3) The rate of officer-involved shootings will vary by size/type of agencies, e.g., state police and Sheriffs will have the lowest rate of officer-involved shootings compared to local LEAs, and rates will be lower for larger agencies.
4) Emphasis on community policing and problem oriented policing will be negatively related to officer-involved shooting.
5) The requirement and length of training in conflict management will be negatively related to police shooting civilians.
6) Required training and use of safety equipment will be negatively related to the number of police officers being shot and killed.
7) Our agency-level variables will be related to police officers shooting civilians and officers being shot at.
8) The number/rate of police shootings will be higher in places where percent minority is higher.
9) A higher violent crime rate will be related to higher numbers of officer-involved shootings, with a possible curvilinear relationship.
10) More gun ownership will result in more officer involved shootings.
11) States with tighter restrictions on the purchase and use of guns and ammunition will have fewer officer-involved shootings than places with more permissive gun policies.
12) At least part of the association between community factors and officer-involved shootings will be explained by agency policies, agency culture, and practices.
13) Our community-level variables will be related to police officers shooting civilians and officers being shot.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a cross-sectional study of randomly selected Law Enforcement Agencies (LEAs) in the U.S. that will assess the number of officer-involved firearms shootings and agency programs and policies over the past ten years.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Using a stratified sample design, a sample of LEAs will be randomly drawn from the 2019 National Directory of Law Enforcement Administrators (NDLEA), Correctional Institutions and Related Agencies (55th Edition), an electronic list (over 15,000 LEAs) which is updated yearly and enumerates every LEA in the U.S, checked against the latest BJS census of LEAs to include all LEAs in our frame. We will restrict the survey to publicly funded civilian LEAs that employ at least one full-time sworn officer with general arrest powers.  The LEA sample recruitment, survey administration, and data collection will be conducted via a NORC subcontract with the Police Executive Research Forum (PERF). LEAs will not be paid for participating in the survey. 

To ensure that LEAs of different sizes are sufficiently represented, the sampling frame will be stratified with the top 75 largest LEAs selected with certainty. Within the second stratum, LEAs will be selected through a probability proportional to size (PPS) method with department size measured by the number of sworn officers. The key advantage of PPS is that it will lead to more efficient sample estimates to the extent that the outcome of interest is correlated with agency size. We will require a sample of about 1,500 LEAs to achieve our goal of 1,000 LEAs (70% participation rate) with complete survey data.  The sample will be weighted such that it is representative of all state and local LEAs in the U.S., adjusting for non-response. 

LEAs will be sent an initial cover letter explaining the survey and a hard copy survey by mail. The LEA may take the survey online or by hard copy. Follow-up calls and email reminders will be sent to non-respondents during the period of data collection.

We will also explore the potential use of existing datasets, such as UCR, local gun law and regulation, and census data, for measures of agency and community correlates, and merge it with our national survey data when possible. In addition, we will select 30 agencies to conduct in-depth interviews with command staff to provide additional context for our survey data.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 1,000 LEAs. We will sample 1,500, assuming a 70% response rate to reach our target sample of 1,000 completed surveys.

q14.value: We propose that a sample size of 1,000 LEAs will allow sufficient precision and power to find differences where they exist. For example, with 1,000 LEAs, we can determine the proportion of LEAs requiring training in conflict management to deescalate hostile encounters with citizens with ±3% margin of error at the 95% confidence level, assuming the most conservative rate of 50%. The margin of error will be even smaller for estimates less than or greater than 50% (for a 10% prevalence we will have a narrower ± 2% margin of error). We estimate that the power to detect a very small effect size at 10% difference (or an odds ratio (OR) of 1.5) between for example municipal LEAs and county LEAs (according to LEMAS 2013 data, 25% of the LEAs are county level LEAs) is 80% (assuming a two-sided test at the 95% confidence level when one of the groups has an estimated prevalence of 50%). We would have a minimum power of 99% to detect small effect sizes at a difference of 15% (or an OR of 1.8). We will have enough power to conduct subgroup differences, such as agency type, size, and region. For example, with 250 county LEAs, we will have 80% power to detect a small effect at a difference of 15% (OR= 0.35).

question.value:
The main outcome variables will be number of officers who were the target of a firearm discharge (including a separate measure of officers hit with a bullet and another measure of officers killed by a firearm) and the number of civilians who were the target of a firearm discharge by police (including a separate measure of civilians hit with a bullet and another measure of civilian killed by a firearm from an officer) by situational factors and officer/civilian characteristics over the past 10 years. 

Predictors will include agency characteristics, training, policies, and methods of recording use of force incidents. In addition, will will merge the data collected with community level factors (crime rate, poverty level, gun laws) obtained from publicly available data sets such as the U.S. Census and LEOKA data.
Latent variable modeling (e.g., exploratory/confirmatory factor analysis and latent class analysis) will be used to combine measures into scales.

We will analyze the collected data in a multi-level structural equation modeling (SEM) framework, to simultaneously examine a set of relationships between multiple dependent variables and independent variables measured at different levels. Using mediation and moderation analyses in a SEM framework, we will be able to estimate the direct and indirect relationship between community factors and officer-involved shootings, as well as the direct relationship between agency-level factors and officer-involved shootings. We will use latent variable modeling techniques (e.g., exploratory/confirmatory factor analysis) to combine measures into scales and adjust for measurement error. LCA will also be used to identify profiles of LEAs based on patterns of officer-involved shootings of different circumstances as well as administrative/staffing factors, policies and programs as they relate to gun safety.

q21.value: Standard model fit indices for SEM (such as Bayesian Information Criterion) will be used to determine and compare model fit. A two tailed test will be used with standard criteria of P-value < .05 to determine statistical significance, that is, the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis was correct.

q22.value: In the case of extreme outliers, we will verify with the respondent and will make corrections if the outlier is due to responding error. We plan to include outliers in the analyses.

q23.value: We will compare agencies that completed the survey to those who did not complete it on available characteristics, such as size, type, and other available information from existing data sources and adjust for non-response bias. We will use Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML)  and Multiple Imputation (MI) procedures, as widely accepted approaches, to address missing data or item non-response.

registration_responses.q1: A National Survey of Police Officer-Involved Firearms Shootings
registration_responses.q2: Jackie Sheridan, Bruce Taylor, Weiwei Liu
registration_responses.q3:
Notwithstanding deeply-rooted concerns regarding officer use of deadly force and officers’ safety in communities, there is a lack of data-driven guidance on mechanisms to reduce officer involved shootings and protect police officers and the public. Media, federal and survey data undercount officer-involved shootings and contain a limited number of community, agency and situational correlates. Despite research demonstrating the correlation between adverse community characteristics such as poverty and officer involved shootings, we have limited national data on this issue. 

NORC at the University of Chicago and the Police Executive Research Forum (PERF) will conduct a national organizational survey of law enforcement agencies (LEAs) to estimate the agency aggregated numbers of the past 10 years of police officer-involved shootings—including both officers shooting at civilians and officers being shot or shot at—and demographic, situational, agency, and community factors associated with these shootings. This is the first national study to assess the number of officers shooting civilians and officers being shot at in the same dataset, and to measure important correlates of these shootings using advanced analytical methods. This study addresses two important gaps: First, we do not have reliable nationally representative data to estimate the number of police officers shootings of civilians, the number of police officers being shot at, and the overlap between the two. Second, there is little research on how LEA characteristics, structure, resources, culture, policies and training are related to officer-involved shootings. 

We propose three research questions. RQ1: How many civilians did police officers shoot with a firearm and how many police officers were shot at in the past ten years, total and by citizen and officer demographics and situational factors? RQ2: To what extent are agency characteristics, culture, practices and training related to the number/rate of officer-involved shootings? RQ3: Are community factors, such as local gun laws and restrictions and gun violence rates related to agency culture, policing practices and required training and to the number/rate of officer-involved shootings? RQ2 and RQ3 will be examined in terms of both overall officer-involved shootings and broken down by officer and citizen demographics and situational factors, separately for (a) officers shooting civilians and (b) officers being shot at.
registration_responses.q4:
We hypothesize that:
1) The number/rate of officers shooting citizens and officers being shot at will be positively correlated.
2) The number/rate of officer-involved shootings will vary by citizen and officer demographics and situational factors.
3) The rate of officer-involved shootings will vary by size/type of agencies, e.g., state police and Sheriffs will have the lowest rate of officer-involved shootings compared to local LEAs, and rates will be lower for larger agencies.
4) Emphasis on community policing and problem oriented policing will be negatively related to officer-involved shooting.
5) The requirement and length of training in conflict management will be negatively related to police shooting civilians.
6) Required training and use of safety equipment will be negatively related to the number of police officers being shot and killed.
7) Our agency-level variables will be related to police officers shooting civilians and officers being shot at.
8) The number/rate of police shootings will be higher in places where percent minority is higher.
9) A higher violent crime rate will be related to higher numbers of officer-involved shootings, with a possible curvilinear relationship.
10) More gun ownership will result in more officer involved shootings.
11) States with tighter restrictions on the purchase and use of guns and ammunition will have fewer officer-involved shootings than places with more permissive gun policies.
12) At least part of the association between community factors and officer-involved shootings will be explained by agency policies, agency culture, and practices.
13) Our community-level variables will be related to police officers shooting civilians and officers being shot.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q14: We propose that a sample size of 1,000 LEAs will allow sufficient precision and power to find differences where they exist. For example, with 1,000 LEAs, we can determine the proportion of LEAs requiring training in conflict management to deescalate hostile encounters with citizens with ±3% margin of error at the 95% confidence level, assuming the most conservative rate of 50%. The margin of error will be even smaller for estimates less than or greater than 50% (for a 10% prevalence we will have a narrower ± 2% margin of error). We estimate that the power to detect a very small effect size at 10% difference (or an odds ratio (OR) of 1.5) between for example municipal LEAs and county LEAs (according to LEMAS 2013 data, 25% of the LEAs are county level LEAs) is 80% (assuming a two-sided test at the 95% confidence level when one of the groups has an estimated prevalence of 50%). We would have a minimum power of 99% to detect small effect sizes at a difference of 15% (or an OR of 1.8). We will have enough power to conduct subgroup differences, such as agency type, size, and region. For example, with 250 county LEAs, we will have 80% power to detect a small effect at a difference of 15% (OR= 0.35).
registration_responses.q21: Standard model fit indices for SEM (such as Bayesian Information Criterion) will be used to determine and compare model fit. A two tailed test will be used with standard criteria of P-value < .05 to determine statistical significance, that is, the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis was correct.
registration_responses.q22: In the case of extreme outliers, we will verify with the respondent and will make corrections if the outlier is due to responding error. We plan to include outliers in the analyses.
registration_responses.q23: We will compare agencies that completed the survey to those who did not complete it on available characteristics, such as size, type, and other available information from existing data sources and adjust for non-response bias. We will use Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML)  and Multiple Imputation (MI) procedures, as widely accepted approaches, to address missing data or item non-response.

registration_responses.q8.question: We have a cross-sectional study of randomly selected Law Enforcement Agencies (LEAs) in the U.S. that will assess the number of officer-involved firearms shootings and agency programs and policies over the past ten years.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Using a stratified sample design, a sample of LEAs will be randomly drawn from the 2019 National Directory of Law Enforcement Administrators (NDLEA), Correctional Institutions and Related Agencies (55th Edition), an electronic list (over 15,000 LEAs) which is updated yearly and enumerates every LEA in the U.S, checked against the latest BJS census of LEAs to include all LEAs in our frame. We will restrict the survey to publicly funded civilian LEAs that employ at least one full-time sworn officer with general arrest powers.  The LEA sample recruitment, survey administration, and data collection will be conducted via a NORC subcontract with the Police Executive Research Forum (PERF). LEAs will not be paid for participating in the survey. 

To ensure that LEAs of different sizes are sufficiently represented, the sampling frame will be stratified with the top 75 largest LEAs selected with certainty. Within the second stratum, LEAs will be selected through a probability proportional to size (PPS) method with department size measured by the number of sworn officers. The key advantage of PPS is that it will lead to more efficient sample estimates to the extent that the outcome of interest is correlated with agency size. We will require a sample of about 1,500 LEAs to achieve our goal of 1,000 LEAs (70% participation rate) with complete survey data.  The sample will be weighted such that it is representative of all state and local LEAs in the U.S., adjusting for non-response. 

LEAs will be sent an initial cover letter explaining the survey and a hard copy survey by mail. The LEA may take the survey online or by hard copy. Follow-up calls and email reminders will be sent to non-respondents during the period of data collection.

We will also explore the potential use of existing datasets, such as UCR, local gun law and regulation, and census data, for measures of agency and community correlates, and merge it with our national survey data when possible. In addition, we will select 30 agencies to conduct in-depth interviews with command staff to provide additional context for our survey data.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The main outcome variables will be number of officers who were the target of a firearm discharge (including a separate measure of officers hit with a bullet and another measure of officers killed by a firearm) and the number of civilians who were the target of a firearm discharge by police (including a separate measure of civilians hit with a bullet and another measure of civilian killed by a firearm from an officer) by situational factors and officer/civilian characteristics over the past 10 years. 

Predictors will include agency characteristics, training, policies, and methods of recording use of force incidents. In addition, will will merge the data collected with community level factors (crime rate, poverty level, gun laws) obtained from publicly available data sets such as the U.S. Census and LEOKA data.
registration_responses.q18.question: Latent variable modeling (e.g., exploratory/confirmatory factor analysis and latent class analysis) will be used to combine measures into scales.
registration_responses.q19.question: We will analyze the collected data in a multi-level structural equation modeling (SEM) framework, to simultaneously examine a set of relationships between multiple dependent variables and independent variables measured at different levels. Using mediation and moderation analyses in a SEM framework, we will be able to estimate the direct and indirect relationship between community factors and officer-involved shootings, as well as the direct relationship between agency-level factors and officer-involved shootings. We will use latent variable modeling techniques (e.g., exploratory/confirmatory factor analysis) to combine measures into scales and adjust for measurement error. LCA will also be used to identify profiles of LEAs based on patterns of officer-involved shootings of different circumstances as well as administrative/staffing factors, policies and programs as they relate to gun safety.

attributes.title: Replication: Music is in the Muscle

item1.value: The interaction/impact of body movements (during music listening) in the development of music preferences. Activation of the positively associated muscle groups led to higher preference ratings for the music pieces than activation of the negatively associated ones.

item2.value:
- First replication of the studie. 
- “The potential influence on musical preferences of one kind of behavior often connected with the listening to music - body movements - has so far been largely neglected. This should not be a one-way issue - how we move might indeed influence what we hear” (Sedlmeier et al. 2011).

item6.value: Lab: “They were each seated in front of a Windows PC in a separate cubicle and told to follow the instructions that would be displayed on the computer screen” (Sedlmeier et al. 2011).

item9.value: The experimental procedure was controlled by a computer program written with the software Authorware 7 (Authorware 7.0 Win Commercial, 2003).

item12.value: Lab University Erfurt (immediate proximity but seperate room).

item13.value: Welcome and first (technical) instructions by myself. Afterwards: Random assignment of the test-persons via computer program. Survey and further instruction by a computer program (SoSci Survey).

item16.value: Power analysis via G-Power (d = .52, Alpha = 5% , Beta = 80%)

item26.value:
- non-execution of the body movement
- mentioned technical problems (playing of the song)
- demolition of the study
- knowing the background of the experiment/hypothesis

item27.value:
Consistent with the original study.

Further control Items:
- degree of performance of the instructed body movements
- degree of performance of other body movements
- knowing of the stimulus (music titles)
- discomfort during the movements
- neutrality of the single music titles 
- musical activities (singing in a choir, playing an instrument) of the subjects
- dominant hand 
- age, sex, education 
- preference of different music genre (especially classical music)

item28.value: Replication of the main-effect = positive movement yielded considerably higher preference ratings than a negative one.

attributes.title: Stress and Coping in Esports: A Qualitative Study
attributes.description: This qualitative approach aims to provide new insights into player’s subjective experience of stress and individual coping strategies, and by that, allow comparisons with traditional sports.

summary.value: Since competition is a key aspect of esports (e.g., Karhulahti, 2017), players have to perform in an environment similar to other competitive sports. In order to take positive impact on players’ performance and wellbeing in esport competitions, an understanding of psychophysiological stress in the specific esport environment is necessary. Although Leis and Lautenbach (submitted) provided an initial understanding of current quantitative research on stress in esports, little is known about psychophysiological stress in actual esport competitions. On the other hand, a qualitative approach by Smith, Birch, and Bright (2019) recently examined stressors that esport athletes faced and which coping strategies were applied by players during competition. However, little information is available about stress responses related to cognitive appraisal and coping strategies, and how both aspects influence players’ performance and outcome of competition. Therefore, this qualitative approach aims to provide new insights into player’s cognitive appraisal and associated coping strategies, their experienced impact on psychophysiological stress responses, and perceived impact on performance and outcome of competition.

attributes.title: Effects of variability in outcome measure and outcome assessors on the prevalence of HAND in sub-Saharan Africa

q1.value: Effects of variability in outcome measure and assessor on the prevalence of HAND in sub-Saharan Africa

q2.value: Martins C Nweke, Uduonu M Ekezie, Nwachukwu Chioma, Okemuo Adaora, Ugwu Princewill

q3.value:
The limitedness of resources available for people living with Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND) in the sub-Saharan Africa calls for strategic planning enhanced by scholarship allocation of resource. In order to achieve such scholarship in strategy planning, the prevalence must be pooled as accurate and precisely as possible, with important cause(s) of heterogeneity correctly captured.  For this reason, the study seeks to ascertain the effects of variability in outcome measures and outcome assessors on the prevalence of HAND in sub-Saharan Africa.
Objective: To evaluate the effects of variability in outcome measures and outcome assessors on the prevalence of HAND in sub-Saharan Africa.
Eligibility: Studies reporting prevalence of HAND among people living with HIV in sub-Saharan Africa, within the past 10 years. Cross-sectional studies will be excluded if convenient sampling technique was employed. Studies will be included provided mention is made of the outcome measure used and the qualification of the outcome assessor(s).
Sources of information: Searches will be undertaken of PubMed, MEDLINE, CINAHL, Academic Search Complete and PsycINFO using keywords adapted from the PubMed pilot search result: “HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder”[All Fields], AND “Prevalence”[All Fields] AND “Africa” [All Fields]. References list of relevant articles will be searched to identify articles for inclusion.
Data synthesis and assessment of heterogeneity: First, the question of the effect of variability in outcome measure and assessor will be answered by narrative. In doing so, all the identified outcome measure and assessors will be presented, compared and pooled in an evidence table. Random-effect model of meta-analysis will be employed to estimate the overall pooled prevalence as well as weighted prevalence for different measuring instruments and classes of assessors. Narrative display of measures of heterogeneity will be undertaken and the measure of heterogeneity, I2 will be computed.
Data analysis: overall, pooled prevalence will be estimated. So also, pooled prevalence with and across measuring instrument and outcome assessors will be estimated. To substantiate synthesized evidence, power for the meta-analysis will be computed and reported. RevMan 5 and MedCalc will be used, with α set at 0.05.
Result and Discussion: The outcome of the study will provide the first weighted prevalence of HAND in sub-Saharan Africa. Results will be discussed in relation to global perspectives. The outcome of the review will be disseminated to inform scholars and policy makers about current prevalence of HAND and factors to consider during HAND screening.

q4.value: variability in outcome measure and outcome assessor will have no significant effect on the prevalence of HAND in sub-Saharan Africa

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic review of observational studies including retrospective surveys, cross-sectional studies and cohorts with focus on the effects of variability in outcome measures and assessors in sub-Saharan Africa. However, cross-sectional studies in which convenient sampling  technique was employed will be excluded. The protocol was structured using a hybrid of PRISMA checklist and the Meta-analysis of observational studies in epidemiology (MOOSE) guideline (Shamseer et al. 2015; Stroup et al. 2008).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data Item
Data will be collected from variables including authors’ references, participants’ characteristics, inclusion criteria, exclusion criteria, study sample size (also the sample size of groups, where available), method  of assessment, instrument used, the assessor’s occupation, qualification and experience, results, conclusions and funding sources (where applicable). 

Quality appraisal and risk of bias assessment 
Quality appraisal will be executed with the aid of the Downs and Black checklist (Downs and Black, 1998). It examines the appropriateness and adequacy methodology, study design, participant recruitment, data collection, data analysis and presentation of findings. It is suitable for appraising most study designs. The tool contains 28 items/questions with a summary score. Ten items focus on the overall quality of the study, 3 items examine the external validity of the study, 7 items concern study bias, six items focus on confounding and selection bias while one item addresses power of the study. Overall, studies will be rated on a four-point Likert scale as follows: excellent (26-28); good (20-25); fair (15-19); and poor (less than or equal to 14) (Hooper et al. 2008). Studies will be judged unclear where information is inadequate to inform judgment regarding risk of bias. However, in such situation, the study authors will be contacted via mail to supply the required information. Non-response from authors will result in exclusion. Reviewer two and three will make independent judgment regarding the risk of bias in consultation with the primary reviewer..

Data synthesis and assessment of heterogeneity
First, the question of the effect of variability in outcome measure and assessor will be answered by narrative. In doing so, all the identified outcome measure and assessors will be presented, compared and pooled in an evidence table. Random-effect model of meta-analysis will be employed to estimate the pooled prevalence for different measuring instrument and categories of assessors following appropriate prescriptions (DerSimonian and Laird, 1986; Wang and Liu, 2016). Narrative display of measures of heterogeneity i.e. study characteristics will be sorted by year of publication, and presented in an evidence table. This will provide information on author’s references, sample size, study design, setting, outcome, outcome measure and assessors. Measure of heterogeneity, the Cochrane’s Q statistics, I2 will be computed in line with Higgins and Thompson (2002). I2 values will be interpreted in line with Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Intervention as follows: 0-40% might indicate low heterogeneity, 30-60% may represent moderate heterogeneity, 50-90% may represent substantial heterogeneity, and 75-100% may indicate considerable heterogeneity (Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. http://www.cochrane-handbook.org).

q13.value: All convenient sampling method will be utilized in which every study that meet inclusion criteria will be used.

question.value: The main outcome will be: 1) prevalence of HIV-associated neurocognitive impairment. The prevalence of HIV-associated neurocognitive impairment is the number of persons that were positive for HIV-associated neurocognitive impairment upon screening divided by the total HIV patients that participated in the study. It is measured in percentage. Definition of impairment varies across outcome measuring instruments. The following are generally accepted cut offs: Mini-mental scale (21, 21, 23, 24 for illiterate, low education middle and high education groups respectively (Kochhann et al. 2010), Montreal cognitive assessment (23) (Milani et al. 2018), HIV-dementia scale (cut off of 10) (Lopez et al. 2016), International HIV dementia scale (10) (Sactor et al. 2005), Frascati criteria for neuropsychological battery tests (Anitori et al. 2007) etc. According to Frascati criteria, cognitive impairment (asymptomatic neurocognitive impairment) refers to mild cognitive dysfunction ≥1 SD below the mean of demographically matched HIV-negative comparator group in at least two neurocognitive domains (Yusuf et al. 2017).

Data analysis
Overall, pooled prevalence will be estimated. So also, pooled prevalence with and across measuring instrument and outcome assessors will be estimated following Wang and Liu (2016). One way analysis of variance will be used to test the effect of variability in outcome instrument and assessor on prevalence of HANI To substantiate synthesized evidence, power for the meta-analysis will be computed and reported. RevMan 5 and MedCalc will be used, with α will be set at 0.05.

q21.value: Random effect model of meta-analysis will be fitted to pool the prevalence of HAND. α will be set at 0.05.
